Este señor labora como guarda de seguridad en el hogar Belén desde hace 8 años este hogar este ubicado en el 10 ½ carretera Masaya. Esta familia cuenta con una pequeña cantidad de tierra la que cultivan para obtener otros ingresos. El solicita el crédito para mejoras de su vivienda ya que el techo esta en muy malas condiciones y cada vez que llueve tienen que colocar muchos recipientes por toda la casa para que no se le deterioren las pocas cosas que con mucho esfuerzos han logrado
texts.en:
Mr. José Humberto B. P. is 48 years old and lives in the San Caralampio La Concepción neighborhood with his wife, Angela Rosa Lopez, who is a produce vendor in the Mercado Oriental in Managua. With the profits earned from the business, she helps out José with the household expenses because they have 2 children in middle school—a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy. After getting home from school, the girl helps her mother with the household chores, while the boy accompanies his mother in search of the next day’s merchandise. They have been selling in this market for 4 years. Mr. B. has been working as a security guard at the Belén household, which is located on 10 ½ Masaya Highway, for 8 years. This family has a small plot of land that they cultivate in order to earn extra income. He is requesting this loan for home improvement because his roof is in disrepair, and everytime it rains, they have to place containers all over the house to collect the water so that it will not deteriorate the few things they have.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair home roof

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Jambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Hawa M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 2 and 14. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependants because their parents had passed away due to HIV/AIDS.

Hawa has been running a kuku (chicken) business since 2007. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing, they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

She works at the business 16+ hours a day, 7 days a week, with the help of her children when they are home from school. She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to build a chicken coop so she has more room for more chickens to expand her business. Hawa thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To build a chicken coop

loans.name: Mrs. Sarun Nop Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank which consists of seventeen members is located in Angk Ta Nu village in Takeo Province. All the members plan to use their loan proceeds for different purposes. Mrs. Sarun N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is beautician who does makeup for wedding ceremonies. Since her business is going well, she wants to use her proceeds to buy additional cosmetic products. Her husband, Mr. Kat Sao, is a farmer. Mrs. Sarun N. is 29 years old and the mother of four children, three of whO. are attending the local school while the youngest one is two years old.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Thirteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows tH. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetic products

loans.name: Birame

texts.fr: Birame travaille dans l'assurance depuis une dizaine d'année. Ce  marié et pére de 3 enfants entretient sa famille grâce aux revenus tirés de son activité. Il sollicite ce crédit pour renforcer son activté.
texts.en:
Birame has been working in the insurance business for approximately ten years. He's married and the father of three children, and he provides for his family thanks to the revenues of his business. He's seeking this loan to bolster his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his insurance business

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy S. is a 33 year old rice farmer who also works raising pigs to sell for another source of income. She raises a sow, then sells its babies, and the business has done well. She is married with four children, all of whom are small teenagers and in school. Her rice crop is one source of income for her family's living, and she raises pigs for more income. To increase her income, Soy S. needs a loan to purchase more pigs to raise.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise.

loans.name: Amele

texts.fr: Amele G. est une revendeuse des légumes au grand marché de Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Agée de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Pour donner plus d’élan à son activité, elle souhaite avec ce crédit payer des légumes pour la revente.
texts.en:
Amele G. is a retailer of vegetables at the grand marketplace of Lomé, the capital of Togo. She is 43 years old, married, and the mother of four. To bring added vigor to her business, she would like to use this loan to pay for vegetables for resale.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy some vegetables for resale

loans.name: Ines

texts.es: Inés tiene 42 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos menores en su propia casa. Se dedica a la  crianza de  animales y a la siembra de sus tierras de cultivo desde hace 5 años, lo cual realizaba como una actividad más para aumentar sus ingresos, pero ahora se ha convertido en su principal fuente de ingresos que le sirve para mantener a su familia. Es por eso que se levanta muy temprano para realizar sus quehaceres, pastar a sus animales y cuidar de sus cultivos, regresando a su casa al final del día. Inés quiere seguir progresando, por lo que desea emprender un nuevo negocio para prevenir posibles decadencias económicas. Es la tercera vez que Inés tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella disfruta de cada reunión de su banco comunal, y es una de las que persevera en la renovación de su crédito. La cantidad que solicita es para la compra de sacos de abono para sembrar papa y también para adquirir una máquina de coser para iniciarse en el negocio de la costura.
texts.en:
Inés is 42 years old and lives with her husband and three small children in a house they own. She has dedicated herself to raising animals and planting crops on her farmland for the past 5 years. She started these activities in order to supplement her earnings, but now these undertakings have become the primary means of sustenance for her family. It’s for this reason that she rises very early to do her chores, graze her animals, and tend to her crops, returning home at the end of the day. Inés wants to continue to progress, which is why she wants to start a new enterprise to prevent any possibly financial deterioration. This is the third time Inés has a loan with MFP. She enjoys the meetings of her cooperative bank, and is one of the members who perseveres to renew her credit. The sum she requests is for the purchase of bags of fertilizer to plant potatoes, and also to purchase a sewing machine to start a business as a seamstress.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa T., 45, is married with nine children.  She has three years of experience in the canteen business. She sells to the general public/villagers four days per week. She has four previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Luisa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase items for her business, to buy home improvement materials like floor mat and cement and to pay for her children's school uniforms and school fees.

loans.use: To buy canteen supplies, home improvement materials, school uniforms and school fees

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en:
Hải Trần (1044061359) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Nghệ An. She is married and has two infant children.

To make a living, Hải works in a family member's business venture in the retail sector selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Hải has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Hải joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Hải has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Hải is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. Hải plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional personal home products to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.es:
WILMA R. H., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las estrellitas de Pucallpa” vive en Asentamiento Humano 4 de junio del distrito de Manantay, en la ciudad de Pucallpa, tiene 48 años de edad y 2 hijos.  Su pareja es taxista (transportista).

Con el primer préstamo recibido de S/ 300.00 pudo iniciar su negocio de venta de comida, con este dinero compró víveres.

En la actualidad vende una variedad de comida par todos los gustos, cocina platos de la selva, la costa y la sierra del país porque hay muchas personas de afuera que buscan ese tipo de alimentos por su rico sabor.  Con este préstamo de S/. 1 ,000.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará más utensilios como son cucharas y platos.
 
“Me encanta la cocina y para que los cliente se vayan contentos preparo varios platos cada día.  Aprendí con Manuela Ramos que como mujer puedo administrar mi propio negocio y así generar mas ingreso para mi familia.
texts.en:
Wilma R. H. belongs to 'Las Estrellitas de Pucallpa' (The Little Stars of Pucallpa) community bank in a squatter settlement called '4 de Junio' in the Manantay district of Pucallpa city. She is 48-years old and has two children. Her husband is a taxi driver. With her first loan of 300 PEN she was able to start her business of selling food, using the money to buy supplies. Currently she sells a variety of food for every preference, cooking regional dishes from the jungle, coastal, and mountain regions of the country, as there are many people from other areas that look for these types of foods for their delicious flavors. With this loan of 1,000 PEN, Wilma will buy more cooking utensils such as spoons and plates. "I love to cook and to make sure my customers leave happy, I prepare a variety of dishes everyday. With Manuela Ramos I learned how, as a woman, I can manage my own business and thus generate more income for my family."

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of kitchen utensils such as plates and cutlery.

loans.name: Téréko

texts.fr:
Madame  Téréko Diakité a 43 ans et vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants à Médine, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle a choisi de faire une activité génératrice de revenus. C’est ainsi qu’elle décida de se  spécialiser dans la fabrication et la vente de la poudre de “Djafarana” il y a environ 17 ans avec une ivoirienne qui était venue à Sikasso pour en faire son activité principale. Cette poudre appelée communément “Djafarana mugu” ou “Tamati mugu” est fabriquée à base de mil, de la graine de l’arbre ou légume de “Djafarana” et du beurre de karité.
Elle pile le mil et la graine de “Djafarana” pour en faire le mélange avec le beurre de karité qui va donner  par  la suite la poudre proprement dite.
Elle  collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts  précédents ont été correctement remboursés.  
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter, 3 sacs de mil, 8 sacs de graine “Djafarana” et 30kg de beurre  de Karité. Elle s’approvisionne en graines de “Djafarana”, de mil et de beurre de karité dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso (Loulouni, Lobougoula, Gnangasso, etc.) sur commande.
La rotation de son activité est très élevée et elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui servira à assurer certaines de ses dépenses, aider  son époux à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Téréko Diakité, age 43, lives in a polygamous family with her husband, co-wife, and their children in Médine, a working-class district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having had the chance to go to school due to societal reasons, she chose to work to earn an income. Thus, she decided to become specialize in making and selling "djafarana" powder about 17 years ago. She learned how to do this from a woman from Cote d'Ivoire who had come to Sikasso to make it her principal business. This powder, commonly called “djafarana mugu” or “tamati mugu”, is made with millet, the seeds of the djafarana tree or plant, and shea nut butter. She pounds the millet and the djafarana seeds to make the powder, to be mixed with shea nut butter, in turn yielding the powder itself as mentioned. Téréko has been collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso for five years now. After several solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association of her area, she is on her second individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. With the current loan, she intends to buy three sacks of millet, eight sacks of "djafarana" seeds, and 30 kg of shea nut butter. Supplies of the seeds, millet, and the butter are gotten in towns surrounding Sikasso City (Loulouni, Lobougoula, Gnangasso, etc.) by special order. Her business cycle is very rapid, and she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used to ensure that certain expenses are covered, to help her husband support the family, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of millet and djafarana and some shea nut butter

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly S. is from the village of Lower Langcangan, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Merly is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Merly owns and operates a business in the food sector, selling hot cake. The main source of income for her business comes primarily from selling hot cake within her local community. Merly has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Merly joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Merly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC.

Merly is now requesting her second loan from GDMPC. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase ingredients for making hot cake. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for making hot cake

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
51-year-old Linda L. is an active member of Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). Her family is blessed to have a large parcel of land yet they lack enough capital to utilize it for their rice farming business. That is why she is now applying for a loan from CEVI amounting to Php 15,000.00. 

Her long-term plan is typical of that of every economically poor Filipino: to lift her family from the mud of poverty. With CEVI, Linda finds every obstacle an opportunity to strive harder. This is what she has learned from the biblical reflections during CEVI cluster meetings.

loans.use: labor, fertilizers and other farming necessities

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia is requesting a loan from Kiva of PHP7, 000, which she will use as additional working capital for her general store, located in the public market of Tumauini, Isabela. She has operated her business for 20 years. She patiently maintains her business in order to provide the daily necessities of her family and to give them a better life. She wants her business to grow more so she is asking for the financial assistance of Kiva lenders. 

Amalia has two children, they already finished their two-year course in college. She is married to Leon, who is a tricycle operator in their village. They help each other to give their family a good life. At the moment, the couple is saving funds for the repair of their house, since their children already graduated from college and are looking for jobs. Amalia hopes that the loan will be provided so they will have a better chance of achieving their goals.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Mrs. Leang Chhum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of twenty-two members, is located in Preak Ta Kaev village in the province of Kandal. The members plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Leang C., who has been selected by the members as the village bank president, is a fish seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Kheng Huot, is a fisherman. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Leang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat for her husband’s fishing. This couple has three children; two are employed in a garment factoR., while the other is a fisherman who helps with his father’s work.

Twenty one members in this group have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a boat for her husband’s fishing

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr: Maïmouna Y. est une femmme de 54 ans, elle marié et mère de huit (8) enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Vélingara Foulbé 2 depuis quatre ans et a une bonne expérience du crédit. Avec ses deux congélateurs verticaux elle développe une activité de vente de crême glacée, de jus de fruits naturels et de bouillie à base de céréales locaux. les bénéfices générés à partir de son activité lui permettent de payer la scolarité de certains de ses enfant et de contribuer à la nourriture et autres charges familiales.
texts.en:
Maïmouna Y. is a 54-year-old woman, married, and the mother of eight children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois de Vélingara Foulbé 2 for four years. She has good experience with loans. With her two upright freezers, she is developing a business selling ice cream, natural fruit juices, and porridge made from local grains. The profits generated from her business enable her to cover the cost of schooling some of her children and to help with food and other family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her capacity to self-finance and to grow her business

loans.name: Maura

texts.en:
Maura is a member of The Dawn village bank. She is 45 years-old, lives with her partner, and has three sons. Her youngest son (16) lives with her and is studying at public school.

Maura was orphaned by her father and was only able to complete fifth grade because she didn’t have the money to continue. She began to work selling sweets in the streets. At 16, she got engaged and decided to become a seamstress. She designed and sewed various bag designs to her neighbors. Next she began to design and sew different articles of clothing to sell.

Since Maura has joined FINCA her life has totally changed. Her economic status has improved and she is thankful for the loans. She encourages her neighbors by telling them that they can progress and improve.

Maura needs a loan of 3000 PEN to buy various rolls of fabric for making clothes and sheets. Her dream is to have a large business that sells sheets.

loans.use: Buy rolls of fabric to make clothes and sheets.

loans.name: Nicaragua Group

texts.es:
El grupo Nicaragua está integrado por Isabel Cristina G. R., Azucena Esmeralda P. G. y Argelia María R. G. originarias de la comarca Altos Norte de Masaya. 

Isabel Cristina G. R. se dedica a la elaboración de Nacatamales, los cuales distribuye en Tipitapa. Esa es su principal fuente de ingresos, ella aprendió el oficio cuando su abuela los hacía y así inició su negocio.  Los realiza por encargo y los lleva a diferentes puntos de Tipitapa para su comercialización.  También poseen un taxi que su esposo maneja y le genera otra fuente de ingresos, el cual le sirve para desplazar sus productos con mayor facilidad. 

Su crédito lo invierte en materia prima para la elaboración de este delicioso plato típico y algunas veces lo utiliza para su carrito.

Azucena P. trabaja en compañía de Argelia R. en la compra y venta de ropa y zapatos de manera ambulante. Ellas viajan a León y ahí distribuyen su producto. Aún que trabajan con capital independiente son muy unidas y se apoyan mutuamente.

loans.use: Compra de materia prima para sus nacatamales

loans.name: Silvia Helena

texts.es: La Señora de Nombre Silvia Helena Rodríguez B. tiene la edad de 42 años, es madre de 4 hijos que laboran de forma independiente y algunos le ayudan en el negocio. Silvia tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000 y siempre la ha gustado ser una persona responsable y pagar a tiempo. La actividad económica es la venta de materiales de construcción, ella da inicio a esta actividad por su papa quien era el que estaba a cargo del negocio ella siempre lucho por mantener este negocio, ya que sabía que un futuro el día de mañana podría serle muy útil para el futuro. Ahora solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de arena, ya que es destinada para la elaboración de bloques. El sueño de ella es que sus hijos logren finalizar sus estudios.
texts.en:
Silvia Helena is 42 years old and the mother of 4 children who work independently now, though some help her in her business. Silvia has worked with the Leon 2000 Foundation for a long time and she has always enjoyed being a responsible person and paying her loans on time.

She sells construction materials. Silvia began this activity with her father who used to be in charge of the business. She has always struggled to maintain the business, knowing that it would serve her well in the future.

Now she asks for financing to buy sand for making cement blocks. Her dream is that her children will succeed in completing their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY SAND TO MAKE CEMENT BLOCKS

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: R. Louise est née en 1985 à Katagon dans les collines au Bénin. Louise vit depuis dix ans à Katagon Anianli et est mariée à NOUDEHOUENOU Zamba, un vulganisateur. Louise et Zamba ont deux enfants tous scolarisés et vivant à leur charge. Louise est une coiffeuse qui mène également comme activité, la vente de produits de toilette à Anianli. Louise n'a jamais été à l'école et exerce cette activité depuis onze ans déjà. Louise achète ces produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Louise sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour accroître son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
R. Louise was born in 1985 in Katagon in Collines County in Bénin.  She has been living for ten years in Katagon Anianli and is married to NOUDEHOUENOU Zamba, a tire maker.  She and Zamba have two children who are both in school and dependents of theirs.   Louise is a hairdresser who also runs a business selling bath items, in Anianli.  She never attended school and has already been in this business for eleven years.  She purchases these items in Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin, and at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo.  She is a former ALIDé client who has benefited from two loans before, which she repaid.  Louise is requesting a third loan from ALIDé for growing her business and for satisfying her customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy personal care products

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
According to her neighbors, Felisa is an industrious mother. Every day, she sells some food, like snacks. Her daily net income is PHP 300. She wants to borrow PHP 5,000 in order to have additional working capital for her business. Although she is currently content with her life, she is facing some health problems; for instance, she was diagnosed with cholecystitis (gallstones). Still, she struggles very hard to support her family.

Felisa is grateful to the people who support her, especially her children. She is married to Gualberto, a painter, and they are blessed with four hardworking children. In total, six family members live together at the village of Cabaruan, Cauayan City, in the province of Isabela. Felisa hopes that Kiva will loan her the amount she has requested so that she can purchase some more grocery items to sell.

loans.use: purchasing more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Marian

texts.en:
This is Marian R.. She is 40 years old, married, and is from Waterloo. She has six children: five boys and one girl, four in secondary school and the last two in primary school.

Marian has been a LAPOSL client for some time now, and has taken three previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Marian sells goods (cigarettes and cookies) in the street in Waterloo town. With her previous loans she expanded her business; with her new loan she hopes to add more goods to her business.

Marian’s goal is to repay her loan successfully.

loans.use: To buy more cigarettes and biscuits

loans.name: Félicienne

texts.fr: Z. Félicienne est née en 1981 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à MOUSTAPHA Latifou un tailleur, Félicienne est mère de deux enfants. Seulement un enfant est scolarisé. Le second n’a pas encore l’âge d’aller à l’école. La famille vit ensemble au quartier Gankpodo à Cotonou depuis près de deux ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Félicienne n’a pas été à l’école.  Pour satisfaire ses besoins, Félicienne vend divers produits (pâtes dentifrices, brosses à dents, pommades) de façon ambulante. Félicienne s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Il y a trois ans environs que Félicienne exerce cette activité. Félicienne a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et l’a bien remboursé. Félicienne rencontre en ces périodes, de difficultés financières. Félicienne voudrait renforcer son capital afin de maîtriser les diverses exigences de ses clients. C’est la raison pour laquelle Félicienne sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Félicienne Z. was born in 1981 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Latifou Moustapha, a tailor, and is the mother of two children. Only one of them attends school, while the other is still too young. The family has been living for nearly two years in the neighborhood of Gankpodo in Cotonou. The couple provides together for the family. Félicienne did not attend school.

Félicienne hawks various products (toothpaste, toothbrushes and pomades) to make a living. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this business for about three years. She got once a loan from Alidé and repaid it on schedule. Félicienne currently encounters financial hardship, which is why she wants to increase her working capital to meet the various demands from her customers. Therefore she came to Alidé and applied for a second loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy toothpaste, toothbrushes and pomades

loans.name: 16.02.04Đông Hải Group

texts.en:
Minh Đỗ Thị (34) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Minh is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 04 Đông Hải (16.02.04 Đông Hải).
Minh is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Minh has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1,800,000 VND a month from these activities.
In 2004, Minh joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Minh is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her ninth from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. Minh plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group
1. T. Thị Mai (98) is a 32-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her food stall. 2. Lê Thị Mai (103) is a 25-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her tailoring business. 3. N. Thị Liên (114) is a 37-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock business. 4. T. Thị Hường (82) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her food stall. 5. T. Thị Lệ (29) is a 43-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her general store.

About Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Minh Đỗ Thị (34) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Minh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 04 Đông Hải (16.02.04 Đông Hải). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán thức ăn nhanh & những loại thực phẩm cao cấp khác trong cộng đồng địa phương. Minh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Minh kiếm được khoảng 1.800.000 VND. Vào 2004, Minh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Minh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 9th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. Thị Mai (98) là 32 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 2. Lê Thị Mai (103) là 25 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 3. N. Thị Liên (114) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. T. Thị Hường (82) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 5. T. Thị Lệ (29) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ropert

texts.en: Ropert L. is a single man who supports himself and his family by selling different kinds of herbal products. He lives in Barangay Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. Ropert has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved his living conditions with the help of his loans from NWTF and through his own efforts. By working hard in selling his herbal products business, he is gradually making his family more economically stable. He now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000. Ropert is now borrowing Php 9,000 so that he can buy additional products to sell. This will be his 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. His previous loan of Php 6,000, which he paid off well within its term, was just another step in his journey towards economic freedom. Ropert aspires to elevate his family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Yoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeun N. is 46 years old. She is a villager who lives in Trapeang Tuem village, Takeo province. She is a group leader of five members. Mrs. Yoeun N. is married and has four children. One of her children works in the garment factory, two are studying in the local school and the youngest one is five years old. 

Mrs. Yoeun N. is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Pang Pol, is a motorbike taxi driver. He owns a motorbike for transportation and he can earn a small income to support his family. In order to help her husband's business, she wants to change his motorbike, so she decided to ask for 800,000 Riel from AMK to buy a new motorbike. She hopes to earn additional revenue so she can improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Delfina Lucia

texts.es: Doña Delfina Lucía Menchú Ordóñez  cuenta con 32 años de edad, es soltera. Es Artesana y se dedica a la “Elaboración de cortes típicos” cuenta con un taller de 2 telares, lleva 10 años de elaborar cortes típicos en su residencia. Actualmente la demanda de su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que ella pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar materia prima y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante su negocio, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Ms. Delfina Lucía Menchú Ordóñez is 32 years old and single. She is a craftswoman who makes traditional clothing for a living. She has two sewing workshops and has been making clothing from home for 10 years. These days, demand has grown, but her financial situation does not allow her to increase capital. For this reason, she now turns to Asociación ASDIR to request a loan with the intention of purchasing raw materials, thus allowing her to boost sales, help her business make progress, and improve her living conditions.


Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to make traditional clothing

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia D. is from the village of  Palao, Iligan City. She is 57 years old. Lucia is a widow with 2 adult children. Lucia owns & operates a store where she sells processed food like longganiza (pork suasage with local spices) and dried fish. Lucia has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lucia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lucia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lucia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Yein

texts.en:
Yein N., 59, is a villager who lives in Srae Vong village, in Takeo province.  She and her husband, Mean, are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice.  Aside from farming, Yein sells grocery and vegetable to support her family.

Yein asks for a loan to buy a motorcycle and to buy more vegetable to enlarge her business.  Yein is the mother of four children; three are seamstresses in a garment factory and the other one is a student in a local school.

loans.use: Buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia B. is a 49-year-old career woman. She enjoys her life playing several roles in the family and in her society. Despite poverty and the many challenges she faces everyday to make her family happy and to maintain a harmonious relationship at home, Delia remains strong and determined to improve her financial status by growing her small and newly established food vending business. With profits from this business, she hopes to achieve her dream of graduating her five children (whose ages range from seven to 17 years old) and supporting the needs of her eldest child who is disabled. Delia’s loving husband supports her endeavor and decision to request a loan through ASHI. He believes that Delia’s skills and determination to manage a business will enable her to succeed in her chosen career. Having the opportunity of having a large amount of capital will make her business stable as well as her profit because she will have the capacity to increase the quantity of food she cooks and sells to people in their village.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of ingredients for her food production

loans.name: Charlen

texts.en:
Charlen L. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Charlen is married and has 3 school-aged children. Charlen owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Charlen has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Charlen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Charlen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Charlen is requesting a new loan, her third, of 11,000 PHP, which will also be used to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Janeth

texts.es: La Sra. Janeth se dedica a la confección de jeans para mujer, labor que viene desempeñando junto a sus hijos ya hace bastante tiempo que se dedica a esta actividad, con la ayuda de sus hijos siempre esta innovando en cuanto a la moda sacando diseños nuevos, justamente este fue el motivo para que ella solicitara su primer prestamo en la empresa, las exigencias de mercado y el crecimiento del mismo obligaron que ella tenga que aumentar el número de maquinas de costura en su pequeño taller, actualmente ella ha demostrado un buen comportamiento de pago en la Institución razón por la cual no se le negó el presente crédito. Doña Janeth cuenta con domicilio propio en la zona Primavera, el dinero del credito lo utilizara en la compra de tela ya que se acerca el dia de la madre y tiene muchos pedidos, esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Janeth makes jeans for women. She has been in this line of work for a long time, and her children have also joined in the business. With the help of her children, she is always innovative in terms of fashion and creating new designs. This was exactly the reason she asked for her first loan for the business. The demands of the market and the growth of the business forced her to increase the amount of sewing machines in her small workshop. She has demonstrated good payment behavior with the Institution, which is why she was not denied the present loan. Janeth has her own home in the Primavera area. She will use the loan money to buy cloth since Mother's Day is approaching, and she has many orders. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they have shown in giving her this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tania Mazumdar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cloth to make clothes.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian K. is currently in the business of knitting and selling tablecloths and is requesting a loan to stock more packets of thread for knitting. Lilian is 27 years old and is married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Lilian hopes to be able to expand her business by stocking bedsheets and dresses to sell. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more packets of thread for knitting

loans.name: Muviti

texts.en: Muviti K. K., 32, is married to a businessman and they have two children, 6 and 10 years old. Her business is located in a busy market in Mwingi that has a lot of goat selling activities taking place. She is, however, served by the Thika branch of SMEP. She has been in this business for the last three years. She says that the business is profitable and the only major challenge she faces is the means to transport the goats to the market. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of Kes 10,000 to buy more goats to sell. In the future, she hopes to give her children quality education, build a family house and create employment for people when her business expands. She describes herself as very hardworking, humble and patient.

loans.use: to buy goats

loans.name: Janarkul's Group

texts.en: Janarkul B. is the leader of this group. She is 49 and a widow. She has raised three sons and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the two older sons went to work in Russia to earn some money, and the youngest son studies at school. In order to make money, Janarkul sells fruit and vegetables in the market. She started a year ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms and now she makes 5,000 soms per month. She applied for a loan because she needs money to increase the turnover of her business and wants to start a wholesale trade. Nurbu A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 24 and married. Her husband works as a truck driver. He transports fruits and vegetables. A year ago, Nurbu and her husband decided to start selling fruits and vegetables on the market. They started with an initial investment of 5,000 soms and now they make 10,000 soms per month. With money received from this loan, Nurbu wants to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she plans to purchase a vehicle. Burulsun B., 47, is divorced. She has raised three sons and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The two older sons work on construction and the youngest son studies at school. A year ago Nurbu decided to try to sell vegetables – she sold all her vegetables in one day and made good money. After that she started selling fruit and vegetables on the market. She applied for a loan because she needs money to increase her variety of fruits and vegetables. Dogdurbek D., 40, is married. Dogdurbek and his wife have been selling fruits and vegetables for ten years. They started with an initial investment of 5,000 soms and now they make 15,000 soms per month. The profit made it possible for them to purchase a house. With money received from the loan, Dogdurbek wants to increase the turnover of his business. In the future he plans to purchase a vehicle. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Sonia Beatriz

texts.es:
Sonia Beatriz R. C. tiene 38 años. Vive en unión libre con sus 5 hijos de 5 hasta 22 años, en el cantón de Ventanas, en la provincia de Los Ríos. 

Sonia es una socia de la ventanilla rural Recinto San Ramón, que esta ubicada en Nuevo San Ramón, a 12 Km. de Ventanas. Son 20 socios en total, que están trabajando en la agricultura de corto ciclo (cosecha en 6 meses). Esto es el primer crédito que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa.

Sonia se dedica a la agricultura, cultivando maíz y arroz. Hace sus ventas en Ventanas, cada 6 meses para maíz y arroz.

Solicita el préstamo para trabajar maíz y arroz: comprar insumos, semillas, y abonos. Piensa que este crédito le ayudara económicamente a tener el dinero que necesita. Su sueño es dar estudios a sus hijos para que sean alguien y que salen adelante. Se necesita capacitación para enfrentar lanchas en el maíz

Le gusta bordar en su tiempo libre.
texts.en:
Sonia Beatriz R. C. is 38 years old. She lives with her five children, ages ranging from 5 to 22, in the hamlet of Ventanas, in the Los Ríos province. Sonia is a member of the “La Ventanilla Rural Recinto San Ramón,” which is located in Nuevo San Ramón, 12 kilometers from Ventanas. There are a total of 20 members who work in short cycle farming (harvest within six months of planting). This will be the first loan they obtain through the cooperative. Sonia raises corn and rice and makes her sales of rice and corn in Ventanas every six months. She is asking for this loan in order to buy supplies, seeds, and fertilizer to raise the corn and rice. She believes that this loan will help her economically so that she will have the money that she needs. Her dream is to give her children an education so that they can become somebody and get ahead. She needs the capability to combat plant diseases in the corn. She likes to embroider in her spare time.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farming supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy zinc sheeting and wood

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina F. is a 52-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two businesses:  farming and rice reselling. She lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Inalad, Siaton, Negros Oriental. Since 2002, she has been a member of Kiva partner NWTF-Project Dungganon and has improved her living condition with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her farming and rice businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000. 

Regina is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can fund her farm operations .   This will be her 17th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Regina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund operations.

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta H. is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old and is married with nine adult children.

Vicenta owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale at the same time, she also engaged into selling variety of products like canned goods, coffee, soft drinks and other primary products. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.She's into sari sari store as another source of her income to provide the needs of the family since farming is seasonal in the Philippines.

In 2009, Vicenta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Toeun

texts.en:
Toeun P., 26, is married with one young child living at home in Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker, typically making US$2 each day.

Toeun P.’s husband sells brooms at the local market, typically making about US$4 each day. Toeun P. would like a loan of US$500 to buy brooms in bulk so that her husband can receive a special discount.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy brooms in bulk

loans.name: Melissa

texts.en:
Melissa A. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. She is 22 years old. Melissa is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Melissa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling of bananas in the local community. Melissa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melissa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melissa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Melissa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing alcoholic beverages for resale

loans.name: Tamaraneh Traders Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kadiatu was born in Makeni city, about forty years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has two children who are in primary school.

For seven years now, Kadiatu has been selling rice, palm oil, salt, fish, etc. retail. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Kadiatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 1,400,000) to expand her business, buying the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

(Also included on the right in the photo is loan officer Daniel B. Banya handing over the loan to the clients.)

loans.use: Buy rice, palm oil, salt, fish, etc. in large quantity

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
José de 41 años, vende frutas con su esposa. Vive en una casa de ladrillos con su esposa y tres hijos en una zona periurbana ubicada a las afuera de Guayaquil llamada Duran y caracterizada por su ecología de disolución. 
 
El papa de José quiso que sus hijos tengan la misma actividad económica que el realizaba por eso le enseño a José todo sobre el negocio. En la actualidad José lleva la misma actividad del papa vendiendo frutas de todo tipo con su esposa. Trabajan desde las 06h00am hasta las 12h00 todos los días. Vende las manzanas a $ 0.30 c/u. la libra de uvas a $ 1.00, peras a $ 0.30 c/u, sandias etc.  

Para seguir con su negocio de frutas bien surtido él quiere comprar frutas y una parte del crédito dirigirla al mejoramiento de vivienda comprando cemento, bloques y asi para darle una mejor vida a sus hijos. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa y tener más puestos de frutas.
texts.en:
José is 41 years old. He works together with his wife selling fruit. He lives in a brick house with his wife and three children, in a peri-urban zone on the outskirts of Guayaquil, called Duran, which is characterized by a deteriorating ecosystem.
 
José's father wanted his sons to pursue the same economic activity that he did; for this reason, he taught José everything about the business. Currently, José does the same work as his father, selling fruits of all kinds together with his wife. They work from 6:00 a.m. 12:00 every day. He sells apples for $0.30 each, grapes for $1.00 a pound, pears for $0.30 each, watermelons, etc.  

To continue with his business and make sure it is well-stocked, he would like to buy fruit, and part of the loan will also be directed toward improving his home, by purchasing cement and blocks. This will provide a better life for his children. In the future, he would like to finish constructing his house and have more fruit stands.

loans.use: Fruit for his business and cement and blocks for his house

loans.name: Odil

texts.ru: Яхёев Одил житель города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот для продажи. В этой области уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en: Y. Odil lives in Tursun-zoda City. He's fifty years old, married and has four children. He has a high school level of education and raises livestock for a living. For five years he has bred and then sold the cattle. He's asking for a loan to buy some more livestock.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Rachana

texts.en:
This is 35 year-old Rachana M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 17, 14 and 12. In 2007, she established her vegetable farming business. Working 7 days a week and 5 hours a day, she supoorts her family. 

She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent one to buy seeds and fertilizers for her farming.  In the future, Rachana plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy clothing

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua N. is a married woman, who sells maize and groundnuts that have been prepared together for consumption in Abura. More specifically, the maize and groundnuts are wrapped together in a corn husk and then boiled. (She is pictured with groundnuts and maize to be wrapped with the corn husk.) The end product is normally eaten in the early hours of the morning. She explains that she has been in this business for seven years. Her husband is a farmer. With her business income, she is able to assist her husband take care of their home.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $225 to purchase additional maize and groundnuts to then be cooked for sale to her customers. She plans to reinvest expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan back into her business.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional ingredients

loans.name: Kiplangat

texts.en:
Kiplangat has been practicing mixed farming for the last three years in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. His mixed farm produces tea, pineapples, and milk which are all sold locally. He is also employed and depends on his salary to cater for the basic needs of his family.

Kiplangat is 29 years old and married with one child who is aged 2½ years old. 

He has requested a loan of 60,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to pay school fees for his children. In the next five years, he would like to have improved his dairy farming by adopting modern techniques.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Majaliwa

texts.en:
Majaliwa is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has operated a clothes business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Majaliwa faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to be self-reliant in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a bale of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeun S. is 28 years old and her husband, Mr. Rithy Chey, is 34 years old.  They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2006 and have two young sons.    

Soeun is a garment factory worker, while her husband is construction worker. She is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase additional construction materials for her husband's work.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her husband’s construction business

loans.name: Hilda Alejandria

texts.es:
Hilda es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de Lujan” ubicado en el distrito de Tinicachi, provincia Yunguyo y departamento de Puno, tiene 25 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente y tiene 1 hijo. La señora realizó estudios de educación secundaria. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace un año, su primer préstamo que fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, lo invirtió en su negocio de venta de tejidos artesanales.
La señora solicitará un  nuevo préstamo por la suma de S/. 1700.00 nuevos soles, dinero que utilizará para comprar cinco madejas de lana para la fabricación de sus tejidos (lliclla).  Su esposo trabaja en construcción civil.
Su sueño es tener una casa y un carro. Le gusta del Banco Comunal las reuniones porque intercambian palabras con las socias.
texts.en:
Hilda is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen de Lujan” which is located in the District of Tinicachi, Yunguyo Province, Department of Puno. She is 25 years old, in a common law marriage, and has one child. Sra. Hilda completed her high school education.

She has worked with Manuela Ramos for one year. Her first loan of 500 PEN was invested in her business of selling hand-knitted creations.

Hilda is requesting a new loan in the amount of 1700 PEN to purchase five skeins of wool for producing her hand-knitted items. Her husband works in construction.

Hilda dreams of having a house and a car. What she likes most about the Communal Bank are the meetings because she gets to converse with the other members.

loans.use: To purchase five skeins of wool for knitting.

loans.name: Pedro Luis

texts.es:
El señor Luís tiene  22 años solo termino el bachillerato, vive en la Zona de Villa Méjico en la ciudad de Cochabamba, el trabaja como taxista vive con sus padres en la casa de su abuela.

El dejo el estudio porque su madre tuvo un problema de salud (tenían que operarla de la matriz y después de eso venían muchos gastos con la recuperación) y su padre no podía asumir con toda la responsabilidad ya que era asumir con la responsabilidad de pagar todos los exámenes médicos como también llevar la comida a casa, es por eso q Luis decidió dejar la universidad porque él estaba empezando a estudiar Ingeniería mecánica.
Luis es una persona responsable desde ese momento el se puso a trabajar primero empezó como chofer y después con el pasar de los tiempos se compro una movilidad que entro a una empresa de radiotaxi para tener más seguridad y poder tener más clientes y contratos de recojo escolar o de otros servicios.

Gracias a la ayuda de su padre y a la de Luis su madre salió adelante y ahora se encuentra muy bien de salud y ella ayuda moralmente a Luis para poder volver a la universidad y empezar su carrera ya que ella se sentirá muy orgullosa de él, al ver que término y cumplió con sus sueños.

Luis solicita el crédito para poder  comprar un tanque de gas a su vehículo y de esa manera poder tener más ingresos  y el desea en futuro terminar la carrera y poderle comprar una casita a su madre ya que aun viven en la casa de su abuela, cosa que no es muy cómoda para ella.
texts.en:
Mr. Luís is 22 years old and studied only until high school. He lives in the Villa Méjico Area in the city of Cochabamba. He works as a taxi driver and lives with his parents in his grandmothers’ home.

He left his studies because his mother had some health problems (she had a hysterectomy and there were many expenses with her recuperation) and his father could not bear all the responsibility since he had to pay all of the medical expenses as well as providing food in the home and that is why Luís decided to leave his university studies as he was beginning his mechanical engineering degree.

Luís is a responsible person and from the moment he began to work as a driver and later, as time passed, he bought a car in a radio taxi company to have more security and customers as well as school pickup contracts or other services.

Thanks to Luís and his fathers’ help, his mother improved and now enjoys good health and she helps Luís by encouraging him to resume his university studies and begin his career now since she will feel very proud of him by seeing him fulfill his dreams.

Luís needs the loan to buy a tank of gas for his car to have more income and hopes in the future to finish his education and buy his mother a home since they still live in his grandmothers’ and that is not very comfortable for her.

loans.use: buy a tank of natural gas to install in his car

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe SABALI sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le quartier de Dougounina de la ville de BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Ces  femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce, de parenté et de voisinage. 
Afin de satisfaire leurs clientèles en nette croissance, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et  le premier a été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt Fatoumata D., compte acheter, 3 tonnes de céréales (mil, fonio, arachides, niébé etc.) auprès des producteurs des villages environnants. Elle effectue sa vente en détail et en gros, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, dans le marché de Bougouni, aux consommateurs et revendeurs. 
Avec ce prêt Fatoumata  D. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 55.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans les activités et l’autre partie dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en: The women of the group SABALI are all married, and they average 33 years of age and four children each. The women live in traditional conjugal extended families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children, and husband. And they reside in the Dougounina neighborhood of the village of BOUGOUNI (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of commerce, kinship, and community. In order to satisfy their clearly growing customer base, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second group loan. The first one was properly repaid. With this new loan, Ms. Fatoumata D. intends to buy 3 tonnes of grains (millet, fonio, peanuts, black-eyed peas, etc.) from producers of surrounding villages. Accepting cash or credit, she sells wholesale and retail at the house and at the Bougouni market. Her customer base is comprised of consumers and retailers. With this loan, Fatoumata hopes to make a monthly profit of 55,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used for her work, and the other part, for family expenses.

loans.use: to buy grains

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr:
MADAME GERMAINE EST INSTITUTRICE DE PROFESSION.PARALLÈLEMENT A SON ACTIVITÉ PROFESSIONNELLE ELLE S'ATTELLE AUSSI DANS L'ACHAT ET LA REVENTE DE TÉLÉPHONE PORTABLE.
ELLE S'APPROVISIONNE PRINCIPALEMENT EN MAURITANIE.ELLE CAPITALISE UNE EXPÉRIENCE DE 4ANS ET A EU A PRENDRE 4 PRÊTS QU'ELLE A SOLDER.ELLE SOLLICITE CE MONTANT POUR AUGMENTER SON FONDS DE ROULEMENT.
texts.en: Ms. THIAKANE is a grade school teacher by profession. Concurrently, she has a business she also works at, the buying and selling of mobile phones. She gets her supplies mainly from Mauritania. She capitalizes on four years of experience and has had four loans, which she has settled. She is requesting this [new loan] to increase her working capital.

loans.use: to buy mobile telephones from Mauritania for resale

loans.name: Elva Rossana

texts.es:
Elva  de 35 años de edad, es soltera, vive en casa de su  madre junto con sus  hermanas, su casa es propia la cual cuenta con los servicios básicos de agua y luz, en la parte anterior  de su domicilio ha colocado  su tienda, ubicado en la zona rural del distrito de Guadalupe a  30 minutos de la provincia de Pacasmayo y a 2 horas del  departamento de la Libertad.  Estas zonas se caracterizan por su alta actividad comercial, agrícola, ganadera y turística  que desarrollan sus pobladores.

Elva se dedica  a la venta de productos de primera necesidad (leche, azúcar, arroz, detergente,  frugos,  golosinas, etc.), en la cual sus  vecinos encuentran toda clase de productos comestibles, con su negocio que tiene trata en lo posible de tener  un mejor nivel de vida.

Mediante una visita a Edpyme Alternativa Elva trata de adquirir un préstamo de 500 nuevos soles para abastecer su tienda de más insumos y así pueda satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes, y de paso incrementar  sus ingresos para cubrir su crédito y sacar adelante su negocio.
texts.en:
Elva, 35, is single and lives in her mother’s house together with her sisters.  The house is theirs and is has water and electricity.  She’s has installed her store in the front part of the house which is located in the rural part of Guadalupe District 30 minutes from Pacasmayo Province and two hours from La Libertad Department.  These zones are characterized by the high level of commercial activity, farming, raising livestock and tourism the residents are involved in.

Elva sells basic need items (milk, sugar, rice, detergent, fruit, snacks, etc.)   Her neighbors find all kinds of food items in her store.  With her business she tries to have a better standard of living.

Through a visit to Edpyme Alternativa Elva tries to acquire a 500 new sol loan to stock her store with more products to meet customer demand thus increasing her income to repay the loan and move her business forward.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen tiene  27 años de edad y es madre soltera de un pequeño niño. Ellos viven en una comunidad urbana en vías de desarrollo llamada La Victoria en Chiclayo, esta es una comunidad principalmente de comerciantes. Carmen es una mujer que lucha por el bienestar de su hijo y espera superarse económicamente por el bien de este.

La actividad a la que se dedica, principalmente, es la recolección de chatarra y su comercialización. Sin embargo, Carmen también cría animales para luego comercializarlos. Ella se dedica desde hace 7 años a realizar dichas actividades y su esfuerzo le ha podido dar algunas comodidades.

Carmen solicita a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que invertirá en sus dos labores. Una parte será para la compra de chatarra (botellas y latas) que luego comercializará y otra parte será para comprar algunos animales y alimento balanceado para estos. Esto le permitirá a Carmen tener mayores ingresos y reducir el tiempo de sus actividades para poder cuidar a su menor hijo.

Para este rubro (recolección de chatarra) Carmen no tiene mayor competencia en su zona y por lo tanto cuenta con clientela fija.
texts.en:
Carmen tiene  27 años de edad y es madre soltera de un pequeño niño. Ellos viven en una comunidad urbana en vías de desarrollo llamada La Victoria en Chiclayo, esta es una comunidad principalmente de comerciantes. Carmen es una mujer que lucha por el bienestar de su hijo y espera superarse económicamente por el bien de este.

La actividad a la que se dedica, principalmente, es la recolección de chatarra y su comercialización. Sin embargo, Carmen también cría animales para luego comercializarlos. Ella se dedica desde hace 7 años a realizar dichas actividades y su esfuerzo le ha podido dar algunas comodidades.

Carmen solicita a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que invertirá en sus dos labores. Una parte será para la compra de chatarra (botellas y latas) que luego comercializará y otra parte será para comprar algunos animales y alimento balanceado para estos. Esto le permitirá a Carmen tener mayores ingresos y reducir el tiempo de sus actividades para poder cuidar a su menor hijo.

Para este rubro (recolección de chatarra) Carmen no tiene mayor competencia en su zona y por lo tanto cuenta con clientela fija.

loans.use: Comprar chatarra  y animales.

loans.name: Benkadi Iv Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe  BENKADI IV sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 24 ans, 2 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KOULOUWO, un des villages de la commune de KABOILA dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
