loans.use: To buy a generator and lathe

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en:
Mastula is a 50-year-old widowed mother of seven children aged between 38 and 17 years, three of whom attend school while the rest are working. She is being helped by her elder brother to pay school fees for the school-going children. Mastula resides in a rented one-room house where she is staying with three people. Mastula doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is no electricity or piped water at her home, but the family gets three meals a day.

Mastula resides in Kalerwe, a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala where she sells vegetables and fruits including avocados, tomatoes, and onions from a rented stall. Working two days a week, she sells to an average of 30 people a day. Mastula’s major monthly expenses include rent for the home and business premises, school fees and medication. She incurs extra transport costs to and from villages to collect her produce. She has been in this business for the past 20 years, her main challenge being the rainy season as the village roads then become impassable.

Mastula has been with MCDT for over six years and is now requesting her 24th loan, working all the time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more boxes of avocados, onions and tomatoes for her business. Mastula aspires to build rental rooms on the plot of land she bought from previous loans. .

loans.use: To buiy more boxes of avocados, onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Yinka

texts.en:
Yinka is 42 years old, married with 4 children.  His children attend school and this makes him a happy father.  He hopes that his children become graduates in the future. 

His wife sells clothes and she also supports their home. 

Yinka sells and repairs electronics to make a living. He is an honest and hard working man.  Yinka is determined to excel in his business and family life.   He is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more electronics to sell.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase electronics to sell.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
35 years old and welcoming, M. Isaac deals in produce and household items in Wakitaka, Jinja. He has been operating his shop since 2005. He became involved in this business as a means of supplementing the paltry earnings from his prior odd-job business.

Once Isaac came to terms with the lucrative nature of his new-found venture, he changed fully to a produce and household items business. Not one to be thrown out of gear as a result of his naïveté, he persisted through the early unchartered troubled waters. That is the reason he cites for his longevity. With this stock in trade, he has managed to cater for all his children’s educational and other welfare needs.

Isaac’s five-year-old business now brings in a monthly income of 150,000 shillings. He wants to increase this profit in the near future. With this loan he wants to purchase more produce and household merchandise to sell on a bigger scale to his clientele.

In the Photo is M. Isaac in his shop at the left with the Credit Officer in the middle plus M.'s wife at the right.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh produce and new household merchandise to sell

loans.name: Morn's Group

texts.en: Mr. Morn P. is a group leader, selected by four group members who will each use a loan for different purposes. They live in Trav Village in Prey Veng province and they are given a group loan. He and his wife, Mrs. Sopheap Mouv, are farmers and own a one hectare plot of land. They cultivate rice on their land and sell it to support their family. Their problem is that their farm is a long way from the irrigation system. To improve production, Mr. Morn P. is asking for a loan to buy gasoline. The couple has two children, one of whom works in a garment factory, and the other of whom is one years old.

loans.use: To buy gasoline

loans.name: Genaro Carlos

texts.es: El Sr. Genaro es un cliente antiguo de la institución, es muy puntual y responsable en el pago de sus cuotas, se dedica a la confección de deportivos y chamarras, y tiene su movilidad con la que trabaja a mediodia y por las tardes, y durante el día se dedica a la confección. Vive en la zona de Pampahasi con su esposa y sus hijos, que están estudiando, su esposa viaja llevando la mercadería a Oruro y Potosí mercaderia que el Sr, Genaro confecciona y donde tiene clientes que la conocen. El crédito será invertido en la compra de tela para los deportivos y las chamarras ya que está empezando la época de frío y necesita renovar su mercaderia. Esta muy agradecido con emprender y kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Sr. Genaro is a long-time client of Emprender and has been very prompt and responsible with his loan payments. He manufactures sportswear and jackets. Genaro also owns a vehicle that he drives around noon and in the evenings to earn extra income, but he spends most of the day sewing. He lives in the district of Pampahasi with his wife and school-age children. His wife travels to Oruro and Potosí, where they have customers, to sell the merchandise that he produces.

This loan will be used to buy fabric for making sportswear and jackets. Now that the cold season has arrived, he needs to produce more items to sell. Genaro is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for demonstrating their confidence in him by providing this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric for producing sportswear & jackets

loans.name: Rrwenshambya Women Farmers, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
It is now eight years since K. Jovia started up her farming adventure in Bushenyi. The married mother of seven children is very aggressive and determined when it comes to business. She has since engaged herself in various farming practices including livestock, which is her main source of livelihood.

Jovia’s main drawbacks include the bad weather conditions like drought, which reduce her rate of milk production since animals lack water and grass to feed on, and also the fluctuating prices which are another setback.

With this loan, Jovia is looking forward to hiring labor, as she is set to prepare land for a banana plantation and beans planting, and also to buy seedlings. She is very optimistic about getting more harvests and more revenue.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and to pay for labor on her livestock farm and plantation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: pay three months in advance on her rent

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen, tiene 44 años, es conviviente, tiene cinco hijos y vive en la comunidad de Rumichaca de la ciudad de Urubamba.  Su principal actividad económica de Carmen es la elaboración y venta de jora o maíz fermentado y con esta malta se produce la chicha de jora. Para la elaboración de la chicha la primera etapa es producir la malta; esta acción es conocida como malteo. El malteo también tiene una serie de fases. Remojo: se realiza en pozos de piedra rectangulares de 10 centímetros de altura y dura aproximadamente 12 a 14 horas. En la misma poza de remojo se elimina el agua y se coloca ichu, y sobre el ichu se riega periódicamente. Esta operación dura entre 8 a 15 días. Secado: basta la exposición al sol y se obtiene el maíz germinado o Jora. Carmen vende Jora a sus clientes quienes elaboran la chicha de maíz.   
   
Carmen participa en el banco comunal y le va muy bien porque es una persona responsable y puntual al momento de pagar sus cuotas, ella requiere el préstamo para comprar más maíz. 
     
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Carmen is 44 years old, in a common law marriage, and has five children. She lives in the community of Rumichaca in the city of Urubamba. Her main business activity is processing and selling dried fermented corn that is used as a malt for preparing “chicha de jora” (a traditional Incan beverage).

In order to make chicha, the first step is producing the malt (otherwise known as “malting”). The malt is produced in a series of phases. First, the corn is soaked in a rectangular stone well ten inches deep for 12-14 hours. The soaking water is periodically replaced to remove any grass or other debris. The entire process can last between 8 to 15 days. The corn is then provided enough exposure to the sun until it germinates. Carmen sells the processed corn to her customers who use it for making chicha.

Carmen participates in her Communal Bank and has done very well because she is a responsible person who is prompt with her payments. She needs a loan to buy more corn.

Carmen is grateful for the opportunity that has been provided. Therefore, she promises to complete her payments by the established deadlines.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn for processing

loans.name: Ream

texts.en: Ream L., 32, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia -- an area known as a favorite tourist place. Ream L. raises pigs, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband is hired to plow rice fields and earns an income of USD 6 per day. L. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more pigs to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more pigs to raise

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina O. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. She is 60 years old. Marina is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Marina operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Marina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and threads. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Marina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment, such as needles and threads

loans.name: Ludia

texts.en: Ludia C. is currently in the business of selling bags of sugar, rice, and beans in her store and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour and baking flour to sell.  Ludia is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a retired teacher. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour and baking flour to sell

loans.name: Joselina

texts.en:
Joselina D. is from the village of General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. She is 41 years old. Joselina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Joselina owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Joselina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joselina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joselina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Joselina is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gulomdjon

texts.en:
B. Gulomdjon is 53 years old man. He is married and has two children. Gulomdjon’s goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals. He is a taxi driver and travels the streets of Kanibadam city in search of customers. He has owned his business for 3 years. 

Today Gulomdjon is planning to buy new and better car in order to earn more money. That is the reason he wants to borrow $1500 USD. Gulomdjon sincerely thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase a new car

loans.name: Gloria Erlinda

texts.es:
Gloria G. S. tiene 33 anos. Es casada y vive en el Cantón de San Pablo en la Provincia Bolívar. Tiene 2 hijos de 13 y 16 anos. 

Gloria es una socia del grupo ¨Integracion Microempresarial¨ de San Pablo de Atenas. Son 14 socios en total, la mayoria que se dedican a diferentes actividades como comercio, negocios, y agricultores como fuente de ingreso a sus familias. 

A Gloria tiene un pequeño negocio de vender pollos por libras. La gente llega a su casa para comprar los pollos. 

Solicita el crédito para crecer un poco su negocio, comprando mas pollos y 4 terreros. Con el apoyo del préstamo mejoraría su vida, por poder poco a poco hacer mas cosas en la vida. Su sueno es tener una casa porque ahora esta arriendo una casa. 

No tiene mucho tiempo libre porque pasa todo el día haciendo quehaceres domésticos y ayudando a sus hijos. Le gusta ir de vacaciones con su familia una vez al ano a las piscinas.
texts.en:
Gloria G. S. is 33 years old. She is married and lives in the village of San Pablo in the Bolívar province. She has two children aged 13 and 16.

Gloria is a member of the "Integracion Microempresarial" ("Microenterprise Integration") loan group in San Pablo de Atenas. There are 14 members in total. Most of them work in trading, business and agriculture to provide their families with a source of income. 

Gloria owns a small business. She sells chickens by the pound. People come to her house to buy chickens.

Gloria is requesting the loan to expand her business, buying more chickens and 4 cages. The loan will help her improve her life, as it will allow her to do more things little by little. Her dream is to own a house because at the moment she is renting. 

She has little free time because during the day she is busy with household chores and helping her children. She enjoys going on holiday to the swimming pool once a year with her family.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more chickens and 4 cages.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.es:
Catalina tiene 56 años, es viuda y tiene un hijo. Actualmente, Catalina vive en la ciudad Andahuaylillas provincia de Quispicanchis del Departamento del Cusco. Su actividad económica principal es la venta de comida y su especialidad es la venta de caldos.

Catalina desde hace mucho tiempo participa en el banco comunal “Las Triunfadoras”. Con su próximo préstamo que espera recibir de S/. 2000 soles, ella invertirá en el negocio y utilizara el dinero para comprar insumos para preparar platos de comida.              
 
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en: Catalina, 56, is a widow with one son living in the city of Andahuaylillas, Quispicanchis Province, Cusco department.  Her principal business is selling meals, her specialty being soups.  Catalina has participated in the communal bank Las Triunfadoras for quite a long time.  She plans to invest this next loan of $725 in the business, purchasing supplies used in the preparation of the meals.  This member is grateful for the opportunity provided through this loan, and commits herself to complete the payment schedule.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies

loans.name: Adela

texts.es:
Adela es socia del Banco Comunal “Sol de Oro”  ubicado en el distrito Juliaca,  provincia de San Román y departamento de Puno, tiene 25 años de edad, de estado civil  soltera y no  tiene hijos,  tiene estudios hasta 3ro de educación secundaria.

Viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 01 año,  su  préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que  le sirvió para  incrementar el capital de  su negocio, ella se dedica a la venta de golosinas y galletas.

La señora solicitará un nuevo crédito por la suma de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invertirá para comprar más galletas y golosinas para su negocio.

Su sueño para el futuro  es tener una tienda de abarrotes.

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro
texts.en:
Adela is a member of the community bank "Sol de Oro" which is located in the Juliaca district in the San Román province, department of Puno. She is 25 years old, is single and has no children. She has studied up to her third year in high school.

She has been working with the field partner Manuela Ramos for one year. Her initial loan of 300 soles helped her to increase her business capital and she sold candy and cookies. She is seeking a new loan in the amount of 300 soles which she will invest in the purchase of more cookies and candy for her business. Her dream for the future is to have a grocery store. What she likes the most about her community bank is saving.

loans.use: Purchase of candy and cookies for her store

loans.name: Julia Beatriz

texts.es:
Julia es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Triunfadoras”  ubicado en el distrito Cabanilla,  provincia D. Lampa y departamento D. Puno, tiene 60 años D. edad, D. estado civil  casada y tiene  05 hijos (01 dependiente y 04 independientes),  la señora  no pudo concluir sus estudios D. educación primaria.

Viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 04 años,  su  primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que  le sirvió para  incrementar el capital D.  su negocio D. venta D. ganados y agricultura.

La señora solicitará un nuevo crédito por la suma D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invertirá en productos para su chacra.

Su sueño para el futuro  es tener una casa en Mala y mejorar su chacra.

Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal son las reuniones y la puntualidad.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of the “Mujeres Triunfadoras” (Triumphant Women) community bank which is located in Cabanilla district, Lampa province, Puno department.  She is 60 years old, married and has 5 children (1 dependent and 4 independent).  She could not finish her primary education.

Julia has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for 4 years.  Her first loan was for 300 nuevos soles and she used that money to increase the working capital of her business selling livestock and growing crops.

She is requesting a new loan for 300 nuevos soles which she will invest in buying products for her farm.

Her dream for the future is to have a house in Mala and to improve her farm.

What she most likes about her community bank are the meetings and the punctuality.

loans.use: To buy products for her farm

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with two children - one attends school while the other one is still young for school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a dress making business for the past six years, and her potential customers are neighbours and school children. Mwanakombo faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During wedding ceremonies and festive seasons she gets a lot of customers, while when there are no weddings or ceremonies the business is very low. She hopes to expand in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan she wants to purchase one roll of cotton material, a dozen zippers, buttons, needles and an iron box. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and run her business smoothly.

loans.use: To purchase one roll of cotton material, a dozen zippers, buttons, needles and iron box.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Kantutas”  ubicado en el distrito Puno y provincia de Puno, tiene 42 años de edad, de estado civil casada y tiene 02 hijos.
La señora estudió educación secundaria.

Viene trabajando  con  el  Movimiento  Manuela  Ramos desde hace 09 años.  Con  su primer  crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, invirtió en su negocio, ella se dedica a la venta de animales.

La señora solicitará un nuevo crédito por la suma de S/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, dinero que  utilizará para comprar animales, ropas de vestir como polleras chompas, sombreros, zapatos y también lanas para tejer chullos y colchas.

Su visión en el negocio es tener una tienda de ropas (cholitas).
	
Lo que le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la organización, puntualidad y la responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Vilma belongs to the "Las Kantutas" [Kantuta Flowers] Village Bank in the district and province of Puno.  She's 42, married, and has two children.  She has a secondary school education.

She's been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for nine years.  She invested her first loan, for 300 soles, in her business.  She earns her living selling animals.

Vilma is seeking a loan for 3000 soles, which she'll use to buy animals, and clothing like skirts, sweaters, hats, shoes, and also wool to make caps  and bedspreads.  

Her vision for the business is to have a clothing store (traditional Peruvian clothing).

What Vilma likes best about her village bank is the organization, punctuality, and responsibility.

loans.use: Vilma will buy animals, and clothing including skirts, sweaters, hats, shoes, as well as wool to make caps and dolls.

loans.name: Mrs. Sao Chantha Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of 11 people who live in Preaek Traeng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sao C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family living. She is a vegetable seller in the local market where she is able to earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. Therefore, Mrs. Sao C. is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. Her husband, Mr. Moeun S., is a teacher in the local school who gets a small salary to support his family. This couple has three children, one of whom is a construction worker, one is employed in pure water production and the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Bernarda Lila

texts.es: Bernarda mujer trabajadora, casada, profesora de profesión. Trabaja como auxiliar de direción en un colegio, su esposo albañil. Juntos le ofrece lo mejor a su familia.  Tiene como prioridad la mejora de su vivienda. Para cumplir con su proyecto de infraestructura ha encontrado dificultades falta de financiamientos para la compra de los materiales de construcción. Gracias a la financiera por el apoyo que se le ofrece con este préstamo. Con el préstamo que solicitad compra materiales de construcción como: Cemento, bloques, hierro, laminas de zinc, arena, reglones de madera, clavos de acero entre otros materiales. Obteniendo protección y comodidad a su vez.
texts.en:
Bernarda is a hard-working, married woman who is a teacher by profession.  She works as a language assistant and her husband is a construction worker.  Together they offer their family the best.

Bernarda's priority is improving her home.  In finishing her infrastructure project, she has come up against difficulties in that she lacks the money she needs to buy  building supplies.  She thanks the institution for the support that they are offering her with this loan.  She will use her loan to buy building supplies such as cement, blocks, iron, sheets of metal, sand, wood, steel nails, etc.  This will provide her with both protection and comfort.

loans.use: To buy building supplies

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.es:
Virgilio es un joven de 26 anos, se dedica a la producción y venta de fajas artesanales y colchas, desde muy joven se dedicó a la venta ambulante, y generalmente realiza su venta por Ciudad del Este.
Es soltero y vive con sus padres en la compañía Tayy Loma de Carapeguá.
Solicita el crédito para compra de telas, colchas e hilos al por mayor, ya que comprando en cantidad consigue mejores precios y aumenta su margen de ganancia.
El cliente opera con Fundación Paraguaya desde el año 2007 y cuenta con buen historial de crédito.
texts.en:
Virgilio is a young man who is 26 years of age. He produces and sells handmade belts and blankets. From a young age, Virgilio has worked as a traveling merchant. He usually sells in Ciudad del Este. Virgilio is single and lives with his parents in Tayy Loma de Carapeguá.

He is requesting a loan to buy fabrics, quilts, and thread in bulk. By purchasing in quantity, he will be able to obtain better prices and increase his profit margin. Virgilio joined Fundación Paraguaya in 2007 and has established a good credit history.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics, quilts, and thread in bulk

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
Getrude N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has four children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Getrude has a business selling soft drinks, which she has had for one year.  She also has a second business washing clothes.  

To help expand her businesses, Getrude has requested a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more soft  drinks for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Getrude hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees for her children.  

In the future, Getrude hopes to own a retail shop. Getrude is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by encouraging her to be independent and to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Peterson Mugo

texts.en:
Peterson  Mugo N. is 53 years old and married to Eleminia Wanjiku, who is a farmer and contributes to the family income. 

He is banana farmer and has been running his business for a period of about three years with an income of about KES 10,000 per month.

This is his third loan from KADET Ltd., and he repaid the previous loan without any difficulty. He intends to use the loan to hire laborers to work on the farm. He hopes to give his children a quality education and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the farm

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose A. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 54 years old. Mary Rose is widowed and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Mary Rose runs a general store. She has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Mary Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Mary Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Mary Rose is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Mary Rose from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve  and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Cristina Angelica

texts.es:
Cristina tiene 29 años y nació en la ciudad de Huancayo. Actualmente, Cristina vive en la comunidad de Cotowincho del Valle Sagrado de los Inkas. La comunidad se encuentra ubicada a 10 minutos de la ciudad de Urubamba donde cada treinta días se reúnen las socias para realizar sus actividades correspondientes. Su actividad principal de Cristina es la venta y compra de verduras y frutas, ella nos cuenta que de la ciudad de Urubamba lleva verduras a la ciudad de Mararuna y de regreso trae frutas. Ya son dos años que trabaja y le va muy bien. Cristina en esta oportunidad requiere el micro crédito para comprar verduras y frutas. 

Cristina pertenece al banco comunal “Kuska Llankasun de Rumichaca” de la Asociación Arariwa  y trabaja con sus compañeras del banco comunal desde hace varios años.
texts.en:
Cristina is 29 years old and was born in the city of Huancayo.  Cristina now lives in the Cotowincho community of the Sacred Valley of the Incas.  The community is located 10 minutes from the town of Urubamba where members meet every thirty days to conduct their activities.  Cristina works in the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables.  She tells us that she takes vegetables from Urubamba to the town of Mararuna and brings fruits with her on the way back.  She's been working two years and business is going very well.  Cristina needs a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables.

Cristina is a member of the “Kuska Llankasun de Rumichaca” communal bank of the Arariwa Association.  She has worked with her friends at the bank for several years.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Thelma Leonor

texts.es:
Thelma Leonor Aguilera es una mujer trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora desde hace cinco años inicio vendiendo cosméticos Avon, marca reconocida por sus ventas vía catalogo actualmente comercializa ropa usada en la que invertirá su crédito. Ella tiene seis hijos de 24, 22, 21, 18, 15 y 14 años la menor.
Ella ha trabajado arduamente para que sus hijos tenga una mejor calidad de vida, estudien y se preparen.
texts.en: Thelma Leonor Aguilera is a hardworking, entrepreneurial woman who began selling Avon cosmetics five years ago. Avon is well-known for its catalog sales. Thelma currently also sells used clothing and it is for this that she wishes to use the loan. She has six children aged 24, 22, 21, 18, 15, and the youngest is 14. Thelma has always worked hard so that her children can have a better quality of life, attend school, and make their way in the world.

loans.use: to buy bundles of used clothing

loans.name: Fanny Esther

texts.es:
Fanny S. O. es una mujer muy trabajadora que vive en el municipio de Soledad y se dedica al tradicional oficio de las confecciones  y con ello a la venta de mercancía, negocio que nació por la necesidad de ayudar a los gastos generados en su hogar;  fue así como aprendió el arte de la costura el cual ha sido muy valioso para ella,  porque  ha logrado crecer como persona y al mismo tiempo ser útil a la comunidad. Este es su primer financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización con la cual  planea fortalecerse empresarialmente, adicionando mediante sus créditos un capital de trabajo a su negocio,  para generar mayores ingresos que los actuales; por eso con su credikiva comprará telas, hilos, botones, y mercancias como cosméticos, porque se hacerca el dia de la madre y está trabajando para responder a los pedidos de sus clientes.
Fanny es un buen miembro de familia, ama a su hijo en la edad de 34 años y a sus nietos con los que sueña verlos convertidos en profesionales de éxito y estabilizados en su propia vivienda;  este es justamente su gran meta más adelante. Ahora está enfocada en buscar alternativas para responder  a sus clientes de manera oportuna y con gran diversidad de diseños y productos que agraden y que ayuden a la sostenibilidad de su negocio,  para hacer frente al desafío que significa la competencia permanente, porque aunque Fanny  logra una rotación alta de sus mercancías, todos los días se prepara para ir un paso más adelante que ella.
texts.en:
Fanny S. O. is a very hard-working woman who lives in the city of Soledad. She works in the traditional dressmaking profession, and also sells assorted merchandise.  She learned the art of sewing out of the necessity of helping with the household expenses, and so her business was born. Sewing has been very valuable for her, because of her own personal growth and at the same time she feels useful in her community. 

This is her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, an organization with which she plans to strengthen her business skills. The loan will add working capital to her business to generate better income than at present. With her credikiva she will purchase cloth, thread, buttons, and merchandise such as cosmetics because Mother's Day is approaching and she is working to fill her customers' orders. 

Fanny is a good family member, she loves her son, 34, and her grandchildren. She dreams of seeing them become successful professionals with their own homes. This is, naturally, her greatest goal for the future. Now she is focusing on looking for appropriate methods to reach her customers with a large selection of appealing designs and products. This will help with the sustainability of her business, and to face the ongoing challenge of competition. Although Fanny has a high turnover rate in her merchandise, every day she is striving to move one step ahead.

loans.use: to purchase cloth, thread, buttons, and merchandise such as cosmetics.

loans.name: Mougnal Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Mougnal est créé le 12 octobre 2010. Il compte 05 membres qui sont très solidaires. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Maoundé âgée de 65 ans (debout à l’extrême droit) est responsable du groupe. Elle  est mariée et a deux petits fils en charge.

Elle vend des fruits et légumes au marché hebdomadaire de sa localité. Elle a une bonne expérience de cette activité pour l’avoir pratiqué pendant plus de six ans.

Avec son nouveau prêt elle compte acheter des mangues pour la revente au marché.

Les bénéfices de cette activité lui permettront d’aider son mari dans la prise en charge des frais alimentaires et scolaires de ses petits enfants.
texts.en:
The Mougnal Group was created at the inception of the Village Bank of Dialicounda Kawral on October 12, 2010.  It consists of five members who are very close.  Their main business is petty trading.  

Madame Maoundé (at the far right) is 65 years old and in charge of the group.  She is married with two children.  She sells fruits and vegetables at the Diaobé Market.  Having practiced this trade for more than six years, she is very experienced.  With her new loan she intends to purchase mangoes in order to resell them at market.  

The profits from this business will allow her to assist her husband in managing the household expenses and school fees of her small children.

loans.use: to buy mangoes in order to resell them at market.
